content: Singaporean footballer (born 1990) **Mohamad Izwan bin Mahbud** (born 14 July 1990) is a Singaporean professional [footballer](/wiki/Association_football) who plays as a [goalkeeper](/wiki/Goalkeeper_(association_football)) for [Singapore Premier League](/wiki/Singapore_Premier_League) club [Young Lions](/wiki/Young_Lions_FC), on loan from [Lion City Sailors](/wiki/Lion_City_Sailors_FC), and the [Singapore national team](/wiki/Singapore_national_football_team). Izwan was also the captain of the [Singapore Selection XI](/wiki/Singapore_Selection_XI) during the [2015 Premier League Asia Trophy](/wiki/2015_Premier_League_Asia_Trophy) against [Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C.) and [Stoke City](/wiki/Stoke_City_F.C.). ## Club career ### Young Lions Izwan began his professional football career with [S.League](/wiki/S.League) club [Young Lions](/wiki/Young_Lions_FC) in 2008 after playing at the [National Football Academy](/wiki/National_Football_Academy_(Singapore)). ### LionsXII In January 2012, Izwan joined the newly created club, [LionsXll](/wiki/LionsXII) which compete in the [Malaysia Super League](/wiki/Malaysia_Super_League). During his time with the LionsXII, Izwan helped the team win the [2013 Malaysian Super League](/wiki/2013_Malaysia_Super_League) and [2015 Malaysian FA Cup](/wiki/2015_Malaysia_FA_Cup) titles. During his time at the club, he was seen being used as a free kick taker during some of the club matches. #### Making headlines in Japan and stints with Matsumoto Yamaga On 16 June 2015, Izwan pulled a magnificent performance at the [Saitama Stadium](/wiki/Saitama_Stadium_2002) which shocked a 0–0 draw between Singapore and Japan. Izwan's heroic displays have drawn praise from Japanese fans and club coaches and also drew interest from several clubs, including newly promoted [J-League 1](/wiki/J.League) side [Matsumoto Yamaga](/wiki/Matsumoto_Yamaga_F.C). Yamaga's Vice-president, Yoshiyuki Kato stated that he was very impressed by Izwan's concentration and ability and gave Izwan a one-week trial at Yamaga. It was later revealed that uncertainty over his ability and the language barrier prevented Izwan from becoming the first Singaporean to play in the J.League, with the club expressing concerns that Izwan was not any better than the local players Yamaga had. #### Heavily linked to Real Sociedad On 16 November 2015, Singapore goalkeeping coach, [John Burridge](/wiki/John_Burridge) said that [David Moyes](/wiki/David_Moyes) was thinking about signing Izwan to [La Liga](/wiki/La_Liga) side, [Real Sociedad](/wiki/Real_Sociedad) as a back-up to first choice goalkeeper, [Gerónimo Rulli](/wiki/Ger%C3%B3nimo_Rulli) but Moyes got sacked a week before so the deal didn't materialized. ### Tampines Rovers In late 2015, when the decision was made by the [Football Association of Malaysia](/wiki/Football_Association_of_Malaysia) to kick the [LionsXII](/wiki/LionsXII) out of the [Malaysian Super League](/wiki/Malaysia_Super_League), Izwan, along with former teammates [Christopher van Huizen](/wiki/Christopher_van_Huizen), [Izzdin Shafiq](/wiki/Izzdin_Shafiq), [Hafiz Sujad](/wiki/Hafiz_Abu_Sujad) and [Firdaus Kasman](/wiki/Firdaus_Kasman) linked up with former coach [V. Sundramoorthy](/wiki/V._Sundramoorthy) at [Tampines Rovers](/wiki/Tampines_Rovers). ### Nongbua Pitchaya After spending two years with Tampines Rovers, Izwan signed for [Nongbua Pitchaya](/wiki/Nongbua_Pitchaya_F.C.) on 14 December 2017, becoming the second Singaporean to play in the [Thai League 2](/wiki/Thai_League_2), alongside compatriot and fellow goalkeeper, [Hassan Sunny](/wiki/Hassan_Sunny), who joined [Army United](/wiki/Army_United_F.C.) for a second stint. It was reported that Izwan took a pay cut to join the Thai side, underlining his fierce desire to try his talent overseas. His move to Thailand was a successful one as he was named in [FourFourTwo](/wiki/FourFourTwo)'s Thai League 2 Team of the Season at the end of the 2018 season. ### Trat After spending two seasons in the [Thai League 2](/wiki/Thai_League_2), on 16 December 2019, Izwan signed for top-flight [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand) side [Trat](/wiki/Trat_F.C.) for the [2020 Thai League 1](/wiki/2020_Thai_League_1) season. ### Hougang United On 27 June 2021, Izwan return to his home country after a long stint in Thailand by signing for the [Singapore Premier League](/wiki/Singapore_Premier_League) side [Hougang United](/wiki/Hougang_United) for the remainder of the 2021 season. Izwan's Hougang debut didn't go as planned as the Cheetahs lost 4–1 to [Tanjong Pagar United](/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar_United_FC). Izwan couldn't preserve a point for his side against Albirex at home after conceding a lobbed goal by [Takahiro Tezuka](/wiki/Takahiro_Tezuka) and ultimately lost to the title holders. Izwan picked up his first clean sheet for the Cheetahs in a 1–0 win against Young Lions ### Lion City Sailors On 8 January 2022, Izwan joined the newly privatised Singaporean club, [Lion City Sailors](/wiki/Lion_City_Sailors_FC) on a 2-year contract. He was used as a backed up goalkeeper behind national teammates, [Hassan Sunny](/wiki/Hassan_Sunny). In 2023, Izwan featured in all of the cup matches which he helped the club to win the [2023 Singapore Cup](/wiki/2023_Singapore_Cup). Midway during the [2024–25 season](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_Singapore_Premier_League), Izwan was chosen as the main choice goalkeeper replacing [Zharfan Rohaizad](/wiki/Zharfan_Rohaizad) after a couple of blunders throughout the season. Izwan also kept a clean sheet during the [2024–25 AFC Champions League Two](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_AFC_Champions_League_Two) fixture against Chinese club [Zhejiang Professional](/wiki/Zhejiang_Professional_F.C.) where he pulled a couples of saves in a 2–0 win. During the second leg of the AFC Champions League semi-final match at the [Sydney Football Stadium](/wiki/Sydney_Football_Stadium_(2022)) on 16 April 2025, Izwan put up a couple of magnificent saves thus seeing Lion City Sailors qualified to a historical [2025 AFC Champions League Two final](/wiki/2025_AFC_Champions_League_Two_final). Despite [Maxime Lestienne](/wiki/Maxime_Lestienne)'s equaliser in the 91st minute of the [2025 AFC Champions League Two final](/wiki/2025_AFC_Champions_League_Two_final) against [Sharjah](/wiki/Sharjah_FC), the Sailors finished as a runner-up after conceding in the 97th minute to finish the game in a 1–2 defeat. #### Loan to Young Lions On 7 January 2026, Izwan joined [Young Lions](/wiki/Young_Lions_FC) on loan for the remainder of the [2025–26 season](/wiki/2025%E2%80%9326_Singapore_Premier_League). ## International career Izwan made his international debut for [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore_national_football_team) in a friendly match against [Chinese Taipei](/wiki/Chinese_Taipei_national_football_team) on 18 July 2011. He rose to prominence in 2011 when he started in goal for Singapore as they defeated traditional rivals Malaysia over a two-leg [2014 FIFA World Cup qualifier](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification) in the same month. On 16 June 2015, Izwan made 18 saves as Singapore managed keep a clean sheet against Asian giants, [Japan](/wiki/Japan_national_football_team) to a 0–0 draw in [Saitama](/wiki/Saitama_(city)) during a [2018 FIFA World Cup qualifier](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(AFC)) match. On 12 June 2021, Izwan played managed to hold 3-time [AFC Asian Cup](/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup) winners, [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia) from scoring until the 83rd minute where [Salem Al-Dawsari](/wiki/Salem_Al-Dawsari) broke the deadlock. On 18 November 2024, Izwan returned to the starting line-up after a 3 years absence with the national team where he played in a 3–2 lost to [Chinese Taipei](/wiki/Chinese_Taipei_national_football_team). ## Career statistics ### Club *As of match played 25 September 2024*.
